summary: This document is an email chain from October 2020 discussing the scanning and processing of approximately 23 boxes of case records related to the Epstein investigation. The emails reference prior scanning efforts in July 2019, the discovery of missing documents and un-scanned pornographic images, and the handling of numerous discs containing digital evidence. It highlights logistical challenges and evidence handling protocols within the FBI.

events.title: Case Records Scanning and Evidence Discovery
events.description: FBI personnel in Virginia scan 22 boxes of Epstein case records, discovering missing documents (1A10, 1A28, 1A84), un-scanned pornographic images of young girls, and numerous discs scattered throughout the boxes.

events.title: Change in Investigation Status
events.description: Referenced as the date "our world changed, and we were no longer doing discovery," likely indicating a shift in the investigative focus or legal proceedings.

events.title: Email Chain on Evidence Location and Processing
events.description: Email correspondence discussing the location of approximately 55 evidence discs from the Epstein case and planning for further processing of 23 boxes of hard copy documents.

keyFacts: During scanning in July 2019, FBI personnel discovered pornographic images of young girls in the evidence, which were not scanned per protocol; the original documents remained in place with a 'possible child pornography DO NOT SCAN' notation.
Approximately 23 boxes of case records existed, comprising materials from two FBI case files, and contained numerous discs that required separate processing.
Prior scanning efforts in 2013 by the Miami Field Office were incomplete, and some documents (1A10, 1A28, 1A84) were found to be missing from their file jackets during the 2019 review.
The email chain indicates a handover of evidence custody and ongoing efforts in October 2020 to locate, index, and fully process all physical and digital evidence related to the case.
The document references a significant change in the investigation's discovery phase occurring around August 10, 2019.
